question: According to the lesson, what is the most common way we perceive an object to be in motion?

options.a: When its mass changes with time.
options.b: When its position changes with time.
options.c: When its color changes with time.
options.d: When its temperature changes with time.

question: To describe the position of an object, what is the essential requirement mentioned in the lesson?

options.c: A reference point, also called the origin.
options.d: The total distance it has covered.

question: What is defined as the total path length covered by an object?
Which physical quantity is described by specifying only its numerical value and not the direction of motion?
What is the shortest distance measured from the initial to the final position of an object known as?
When is an object said to be in uniform motion according to the lesson?

options.a: When it covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time.
options.b: When it covers equal distances in equal intervals of time.
options.c: When its velocity changes at a non-uniform rate.
options.d: When its speed is not constant.

question: What type of motion occurs when an object covers unequal distances in equal intervals of time?
What is the quantity referred to as speed?

options.a: The total time taken to cover a distance.
options.c: The distance travelled by the object in unit time.
options.d: The change in velocity per unit time.

question: What is the SI unit of speed?
What is the quantity that specifies both the speed of an object and its direction of motion?
How can the velocity of an object be changed?

options.b: By changing its speed, direction of motion, or both.
options.c: By changing only the reference point.

question: For an object whose velocity is changing at a uniform rate, how is average velocity calculated?

options.a: Total distance travelled divided by total time taken.
options.b: Product of initial and final velocity.
options.d: Arithmetic mean of initial velocity and final velocity.

question: What is the SI unit of acceleration?
When is acceleration taken to be negative?

options.a: When it is in the direction of velocity.
options.b: When it is perpendicular to the direction of velocity.
options.c: When it is opposite to the direction of velocity.

question: What is an example of uniformly accelerated motion according to the lesson?

options.a: A car moving on a crowded street.
options.b: A person jogging in a park.
options.c: The motion of a freely falling body.
options.d: A car travelling along a straight road increasing its speed by unequal amounts.

question: In a distance-time graph, what is plotted along the x-axis?
What does a straight line graph represent for uniform speed on a distance-time graph?

options.a: Distance is decreasing at a uniform rate.
options.b: Distance is increasing at a non-uniform rate.
options.c: Distance is increasing at a uniform rate.

question: What does the slope of a distance-time graph represent?
What does the area enclosed by the velocity-time graph and the time axis represent?
Which equation of motion describes the velocity-time relation for an object moving with uniform acceleration?
Which equation of motion represents the position-time relation?
What is the motion of an object called if it moves in a circular path with uniform speed?
Why is uniform circular motion considered an accelerated motion?

options.b: Because the direction of motion continuously changes.
options.c: Because the radius of the path changes.
options.d: Because the time period is constant.

question: An odometer is a device fitted in automobiles. What does it measure?

options.b: The time taken for a journey.

question: What is the numerical value of a physical quantity called?
Which of the following is true for the object moving back to its initial position O, as described in Fig. 7.1?
For an object moving along a straight line with uniform velocity, how does the velocity change with time?
When describing motion, what is the 'origin'?

options.a: The final position of the object.
options.b: The point where the object changes its direction.
options.c: The reference point from which the position of an object is specified.
options.d: The point where the object comes to rest.

question: What does a straight line parallel to the x-axis on a velocity-time graph represent?
Which of the following physical quantities is always positive or zero?
An object travels 16 m in 4 s and then another 16 m in 2 s. What is the average speed of the object?
The odometer of a car reads 2000 km at the start of a trip and 2400 km at the end of the trip. If the trip took 8 h, calculate the average speed of the car in km h⁻¹.
Usha swims in a 90 m long pool. She covers 180 m in one minute by swimming from one end to the other and back along the same straight path. What is Usha's average speed?
Usha swims in a 90 m long pool. She covers 180 m in one minute by swimming from one end to the other and back along the same straight path. What is Usha's average velocity?
Starting from a stationary position, Rahul paddles his bicycle to attain a velocity of 6 m s⁻¹ in 30 s. Calculate the acceleration of the bicycle in this case.
After attaining a velocity of 6 m s⁻¹, Rahul applies brakes such that the velocity of the bicycle comes down to 4 m s⁻¹ in the next 5 s. Calculate the acceleration of the bicycle during braking.
A train starting from rest attains a velocity of 72 km h⁻¹ in 5 minutes. Assuming uniform acceleration, what is the acceleration of the train?
A train starting from rest attains a velocity of 72 km h⁻¹ in 5 minutes. Assuming uniform acceleration, what is the distance travelled by the train for attaining this velocity?
A car accelerates uniformly from 18 km h⁻¹ to 36 km h⁻¹ in 5 s. Calculate the acceleration of the car.
A car accelerates uniformly from 18 km h⁻¹ to 36 km h⁻¹ in 5 s. Calculate the distance covered by the car in that time.

The brakes applied to a car produce an acceleration of 6 m s⁻² in the opposite direction to the motion. If the car takes 2 s to stop after the application of brakes, calculate the initial speed of the car before braking.
A car with an initial speed of 12 m s⁻¹ applies brakes producing an acceleration of -6 m s⁻². If it takes 2 s to stop, what distance does it travel during this time?
A bus starts from rest and moves with a uniform acceleration of 0.1 m s⁻² for 2 minutes. What is the speed acquired by the bus?
A bus starts from rest and moves with a uniform acceleration of 0.1 m s⁻² for 2 minutes. What is the distance travelled by the bus?
A train is travelling at a speed of 90 km h⁻¹. Brakes are applied to produce a uniform acceleration of -0.5 m s⁻². How far will the train go before it is brought to rest?
A trolley, while going down an inclined plane, has an acceleration of 2 cm s⁻². What will be its velocity 3 s after the start?
A racing car has a uniform acceleration of 4 m s⁻². What distance will it cover in 10 s after start?

A signal from a spaceship reached the ground station in five minutes. If the signal travels at the speed of light, that is, 3 × 10⁸ m s⁻¹, what was the distance of the spaceship from the ground station?
An athlete completes one round of a circular track of diameter 200 m in 40 s. What is the distance covered by the athlete in one round?
An athlete completes one round of a circular track of diameter 200 m in 40 s. What will be the magnitude of displacement at the end of 40 s?
Joseph jogs from one end A to the other end B of a straight 300 m road in 2 minutes 30 seconds. What is Joseph’s average speed from A to B?
Joseph jogs from one end A to the other end B of a straight 300 m road in 2 minutes 30 seconds. What is Joseph’s average velocity from A to B?

Joseph jogs from one end A to the other end B of a straight 300 m road in 2 minutes 30 seconds and then turns around and jogs 100 m back to point C in another 1 minute. What is Joseph's average speed from A to C?

Joseph jogs from one end A to the other end B of a straight 300 m road in 2 minutes 30 seconds and then turns around and jogs 120 m back to point C in another 1 minute. What is Joseph's average velocity from A to C?

Abdul drives to school, computing his average speed for the trip to be 20 km h⁻¹. On his return trip along the same route, the average speed is 30 km h⁻¹. What is the average speed for Abdul’s entire trip?
A motorboat starting from rest on a lake accelerates in a straight line at a constant rate of 3.0 m s⁻² for 8.0 s. How far does the boat travel during this time?
A ball is gently dropped from a height of 20 m. If its velocity increases uniformly at the rate of 10 m s⁻², with what velocity will it strike the ground?
A ball is gently dropped from a height of 20 m. If its velocity increases uniformly at the rate of 10 m s⁻², how much time will it take to strike the ground?
An artificial satellite is moving in a circular orbit of radius 42250 km. Calculate its speed if it takes 24 hours to revolve around the earth.
A bus decreases its speed from 80 km h⁻¹ to 60 km h⁻¹ in 5 s. Find the acceleration of the bus.
When a person is standing on the roadside and perceives a bus along with its passengers as moving, while a passenger inside the bus sees his fellow passengers at rest, this scenario best illustrates:

options.a: That motion is an absolute phenomenon.
options.b: That all objects are always in motion.

question: Why are average speed and average velocity often used to describe the rate of motion in everyday life, for instance, when a car is moving on a crowded street?

options.a: Because cars always maintain a uniform speed.
options.b: Because actual speed and velocity are too difficult to measure.
options.c: Because motion in such situations is typically non-uniform.
options.d: Because average values are always equal to instantaneous values.

question: The sound of thunder takes some time to reach you after you see the lightning. This phenomenon is an application of understanding:

options.b: The difference in speed of light and sound.

question: Why are drivers cautioned to maintain some distance between vehicles while travelling on the road?

options.c: To account for the distance a vehicle travels before stopping after brakes are applied.
options.d: To reduce the average speed of the vehicle.

question: The motion of the moon around the earth and a satellite in a circular orbit around the earth are examples of:
When an athlete throws a hammer or a discus in a sports meet, it moves along the direction it was moving at the time it was released. This demonstrates that:

options.a: The object stops immediately upon release.
options.b: Objects in circular motion are always at rest.
options.c: Objects tend to continue moving tangentially to their circular path upon release.
options.d: The acceleration of the object is zero upon release.

question: The generation of hydro-electric power by the flow of water is given as an example of:

options.d: Motion that does not require study.

question: If you infer the motion of air by observing the movement of dust and the movement of leaves and branches of trees, this is an example of:

options.d: Describing motion using a reference point.

question: In which of the following scenarios is the magnitude of average velocity of an object equal to its average speed?

options.a: A car moving on a crowded street.
options.b: A person jogging in a park (non-uniform path).
options.c: An object moving along a straight line without changing direction.
options.d: A farmer completing one round of a square field.

question: If a cricket bowler bowls at 143 km h⁻¹, this value specifies:

options.b: The average velocity of the ball.

question: When an object's velocity is decreasing with time, as shown in Fig. 7.7(a) velocity-time graph, it represents:
Consider a car that is increasing its speed by unequal amounts in equal intervals of time while travelling along a straight road. This type of motion is best described as:
The phenomenon of sunrise, sunset, and changing of seasons is caused by:
We sometimes are endangered by the motion of objects around us, especially if that motion is erratic and uncontrolled. Examples provided in the lesson include:

options.c: A flooded river, a hurricane, or a tsunami.
options.d: A bicycle moving on a straight road.

question: To determine the speed of an object from a distance-time graph, one should calculate:
If an object travels in a straight line and its velocity increases or decreases by equal amounts in equal intervals of time, its motion is described as:
What could be the motion of an object if its velocity-time graph is a curved line?
A linear equation having two variables can be solved using which type of graph as studied in mathematics?
In a cricket match telecast, what type of graph is typically used to show the run rate of a team in each over?
Which type of motion is considered the simplest?
An object has moved through a distance. Based on the lesson, under what condition can it have zero displacement?

options.a: Only if the object did not move at all.
options.b: Only if the object moved in a perfect circle.
options.c: If the object's final position coincides with its initial position.
options.d: If the object travelled at a very slow speed.

question: Consider the data in Table 7.1 for two objects, A and B. Object A's distances are 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70 m at 15-minute intervals. Object B's distances are 12, 19, 23, 35, 37, 41, 44 m at 15-minute intervals. What can be concluded about their motions?

options.a: Both objects are in non-uniform motion.
options.b: Both objects are in uniform motion.
options.c: Object A is in uniform motion, and Object B is in non-uniform motion.
options.d: Object A is in non-uniform motion, and Object B is in uniform motion.

question: An object's distance-time graph is a straight line parallel to the time axis. What can be concluded about the motion of this object?

options.a: The object is moving with uniform speed.
options.d: The object is moving with non-uniform speed.

question: An object's speed-time graph is a straight line parallel to the time axis. What can be concluded about the motion of this object?

options.b: The object is moving with uniform velocity.
options.c: The object is undergoing non-uniform acceleration.
options.d: The object is moving with uniform acceleration.

question: In the context of the rectangular, hexagonal, and octagonal tracks discussed for an athlete, what happens to the number of times the athlete has to change direction as the number of sides of the track increases indefinitely?

options.b: The number of changes remains constant.
options.c: The number of changes increases, approaching continuous change.

question: The velocity-time graph for a car shows a straight line sloping downwards (as in Fig. 7.7a). What does this graph indicate about the car's motion?

options.c: The car is moving with uniform velocity.

question: If the initial and final positions of an object coincide, but it covered a certain path length, which of the following statements is true based on the lesson?

options.a: Its distance covered is zero, but displacement is non-zero.
options.b: Both its distance and displacement are zero.
options.c: Its distance covered is non-zero, and its displacement is also non-zero.
options.d: Its distance covered is non-zero, but its displacement is zero.

question: Why is it difficult to directly perceive the motion of the Earth, even though it causes phenomena like sunrise and sunset?

options.a: Earth's motion is too slow to be noticed.
options.b: We are also moving along with the Earth at the same velocity.
options.c: Earth's motion is erratic and uncontrolled.
options.d: Motion only occurs relative to other planets.

question: An object is observed to be vibrating. According to the lesson, what type of motion is this?
How can the change in velocity of an object be expressed mathematically?

options.a: Product of initial and final velocity.
options.b: Final velocity divided by initial velocity.

question: If a distance-time graph shows a non-linear variation of the distance travelled by an object with time, what kind of motion does it represent?
An object travels from point O to A (60km) and then back to B (35km from O) along the same straight path. If the total time taken is T, how would you calculate the average velocity?
What distinguishes speed from velocity?

options.a: Speed can be negative, but velocity cannot.
options.b: Speed is a vector quantity, while velocity is a scalar quantity.
options.c: Speed only requires magnitude, while velocity requires both magnitude and direction.
options.d: Speed is measured in m/s², while velocity is measured in m/s.

question: If a body is undergoing uniform acceleration, what can be said about its velocity?

options.b: Its velocity changes by unequal amounts in equal intervals of time.
options.c: Its velocity changes by equal amounts in equal intervals of time.

question: The length of each side of a multi-sided track decreases to a point as the number of sides increases indefinitely. What shape does the track approach?
Which type of motion would be represented by a velocity-time graph that is a straight line sloping upwards from the origin?

options.b: An object moving with uniform velocity.
options.c: An object moving with uniform acceleration, starting from rest.
options.d: An object moving with non-uniform acceleration.

question: Why is it necessary to specify a reference point (origin) to describe the location of an object?

options.c: To have a fixed position relative to which the object's position can be stated.
options.d: To know the type of material the object is made of.

question: Which of the following conditions ensures that an object's speed is constant, but its velocity is changing?

options.a: Moving in a straight line at constant acceleration.
options.b: Moving along a straight line at constant speed.
options.c: Moving in a circular path at constant speed.

question: If a train appears to move while you are sitting in it at a station, but it is actually at rest, this experience highlights:

options.b: The concept of relative motion and perception.
options.c: A flaw in the train's braking system.
options.d: The influence of Earth's rotation on perception.

question: A car travels a distance of 100 km in 2 h. The lesson states its average speed is 50 km h⁻¹. What can be concluded about the car's instantaneous speed during this trip?

options.a: The car travelled exactly at 50 km h⁻¹ all the time.
options.b: The car travelled faster than 50 km h⁻¹ at all times.
options.c: The car might have travelled faster or slower than 50 km h⁻¹ at different times.
options.d: The car was always at rest for parts of the journey.

question: Assertion (A): An object in uniform circular motion is considered to be in accelerated motion. Reason (R): In uniform circular motion, the direction of motion changes continuously.

options.b: Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
options.c: A is true but R is false.
options.d: A is false but R is true.

options.c: A is true but R is false.

question: Assertion (A): A car moving on a crowded street is an example of non-uniform motion. Reason (R): In non-uniform motion, objects cover unequal distances in equal intervals of time.

options.b: Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.

question: Assertion (A): The position-velocity relation equation 2as = v² – u² can be obtained from the other two equations of motion. Reason (R): This equation is derived by eliminating time (t) from the velocity-time and position-time relations.

options.d: A is false but R is true.
